results.name: Deep account research
results.output:
Here’s a concise, sales-ready Boeing brief (as of Oct 7, 2025).

Company snapshot
- Ticker: NYSE: BA | HQ: 929 Long Bridge Dr, Arlington, VA. CEO: Kelly Ortberg (since Aug 8, 2024). Employees: ~172,000 (FY2024). ([mapquest.com](https://www.mapquest.com/us/virginia/the-boeing-company-east-coast-headquarters-442389469?utm_source=openai))
- Segments: Commercial Airplanes (BCA); Defense, Space & Security (BDS); Global Services (BGS); Boeing Capital. Backlog Q2’25: ~$619B, incl. >5,900 commercial aircraft. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx?utm_source=openai))

Financials & performance (latest)
- Q2’25: Revenue $22.7B; free cash flow −$0.2B; debt $53.3B; backlog $619B. FY2024 net loss ~$11.8B. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx?utm_source=openai))
- Segment notes (Q2’25): BCA revenue $10.9B (150 deliveries). BDS revenue $6.6B; margin 1.7%; backlog ~$74B. BGS revenue $5.3B; margin 19.9%. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx?utm_source=openai))

Programs, milestones, outlook
- 737 MAX: FAA cap has limited production to ~38/mo; reports suggest prep to lift to 42/mo as soon as Oct 2025 (not yet independently verified). Certification of -7/-10 now widely expected in 2026 (customer commentary). ([barrons.com](https://www.barrons.com/articles/boeing-stock-faa-max-production-1f852bb0?utm_source=openai))
- 787: Production ~7/mo (Q2’25). FAA oversight of airworthiness certs easing back to shared model. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx?utm_source=openai))
- 777X: Entry into service now targeted for early 2027 per multiple reports; financial charge possible. ([investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/boeing-777x-to-be-delayed-to-2027-bloomberg-news-reports-4269379?utm_source=openai))
- BDS highlights: Awards include USAF T‑7A production-representative aircraft; MQ‑25 ground testing started. Deliveries across F‑15, KC‑46, AH‑64, CH‑47, P‑8 continue. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx))
- Space: Starliner CFT issues led to uncrewed return in Sept 2024; astronauts returned later via Dragon. Ongoing propulsion system testing into 2025. ([nasa.gov](https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/boeing-crew-flight-test/2024/08/24/nasa-decides-to-bring-starliner-spacecraft-back-to-earth-without-crew/?utm_source=openai))

Quality, safety, and regulatory
- Post‑Alaska 1282, FAA mandated a 90‑day plan to address systemic quality controls; Boeing published a Safety & Quality Plan and actions aligned to FAA panel recommendations; usage of internal safety reporting rose significantly. ([cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/02/28/faa-gives-boeing-90-days-for-quality-control-on-737-max.html?utm_source=openai))
- DOJ/737 MAX legal case: Judge set a June 23, 2025 trial date after rejecting an earlier plea deal; status remains an ongoing legal risk. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/us-judge-sets-boeing-737-max-fraud-trial-june-23-2025-03-25/?utm_source=openai))

M&A and supply chain
- Spirit AeroSystems: Definitive deal announced July 1, 2024; shareholders approved Jan 31, 2025. Expected close now Q4’25, concurrent with divestiture of Airbus programs to Airbus; FTC second request issued. ([spiritaero.com](https://www.spiritaero.com/pages/release/spirit-aerosystems-announces-acquisition-by-boeing-in-8.3-billion-transaction/?utm_source=openai))

Supplier/partner requirements (how to engage)
- Register: Boeing Supplier Capability Assessment DB; access via Exostar; Supplier Portal requires Exostar MAG credentials. ([boeingsuppliers.com](https://www.boeingsuppliers.com/become?utm_source=openai))
- Cybersecurity: NIST SP 800‑171, DFARS 252.204‑7012; Boeing Terms of Use & Cybersecurity Supplement (SP5); CMMC rollout—expect Level 2 for most DIB work. ([boeingsuppliers.com](https://www.boeingsuppliers.com/become/cybersecurity?utm_source=openai))

Key sites and entry points (prospecting)
- Commercial: Renton (737), Everett (777/767), North Charleston (787). Defense: St. Louis (fighters, MQ‑25), Mesa (Apache), Philadelphia (H‑47/V‑22), Huntsville (space). Use cases: production quality, digital thread/MBSE, supplier quality, inspection automation, training. ([investors.boeing.com](https://investors.boeing.com/investors/news/press-release-details/2025/Boeing-Reports-Second-Quarter-Results/default.aspx))

Recent headlines to know
- Potential 737 production ramp toward 42/mo; no near‑term “new airplane” launch; 777X delay chatter. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/boeing-said-prepare-737-output-hike-soon-october-bloomberg-news-reports-2025-10-06/?utm_source=openai))

Why this matters for Nevereverordinary Labs (A&D)
- Hot-button priorities: raise first-pass yield, defect detection, auditability (FAA/DOJ scrutiny), supplier performance, CMMC readiness, digital continuity across BCA/BDS/BGS.
- Likely buyers/sponsors: VP/Dir Manufacturing Quality; VP Safety & Quality Transformation; BCA/BDS Program Chiefs; Supplier Quality Ops; BGS Digital Solutions.

Discovery questions (fast)
- Where are your top three quality escape modes on 737/787/777 lines today, and what’s the time-to-detect vs. time-to-correct?
- Which supplier tiers drive the most rework/delays post‑Spirit integration?
- What’s the current DPPM/FPY target by program and the digital traceability gaps preventing it?
- How are you operationalizing the Safety & Quality Plan metrics at the cell/shift level?
- CMMC Level 2: which environments and data flows are still not assessment‑ready?

Land-and-expand motion
- Land: pilot AI-assisted inspection/defect analytics on a single fuselage/structure workcell or a high-defect station at Renton or North Charleston.
- Expand: supplier quality analytics across Spirit‑legacy work packages; then roll to BDS final assembly/test; tie into training/recert flows (BGS).

Objections to expect
- “Regulatory freeze/limited change bandwidth.” Counter with low‑lift pilots that map to FAA metrics and existing SMS/QMS dashboards. ([boeing.com](https://www.boeing.com/strengthening-safety-and-quality?utm_source=openai))
- “Supplier data access.” Counter with secure, CUI‑compliant pipelines aligned to NIST 800‑171/CMMC. ([boeingsuppliers.com](https://www.boeingsuppliers.com/become/cybersecurity?utm_source=openai))

Want me to tailor this into a one-pager for your meeting, with target stakeholders at BCA vs. BDS and a 30‑minute agenda?

issues: No proactive greeting or use of the user's name/company
Does not surface upcoming meetings or provide prep tied to a specific calendar
Lacks an explicit executive summary up front (starts with snapshot, not key takeaways + next steps)
Some facts appear outdated or insufficiently verified for Oct 2025 (e.g., DOJ trial date status, CEO naming) and lack authoritative sourcing
Uses weaker/secondary sources for basic facts (e.g., MapQuest for HQ) instead of primary sources
Contains speculative language without clear verification (e.g., 737 ramp "reports suggest")
Decision-maker section lists roles but no named contacts; could be more actionable
Length may exceed a crisp <3-minute read target
Did not follow the "stream short deltas" policy; delivered a single long block
improvements: Open with a brief, personalized greeting that uses the user's name and Nevereverordinary Labs, and sets context
Add a 4–6 bullet executive summary at the very top: top 3–5 signals, why they matter, and a recommended next step
Surface hot signals with an explicit Action line for each tying to Nevereverordinary Labs capabilities
Include an Upcoming meetings/prep section with a proposed 30-minute agenda, key questions, and pre-read links; ask for calendar access if unavailable
Name at least two specific Boeing decision-makers (titles + links) for BCA and BDS to increase actionability
Replace secondary sources with primary ones (Boeing IR/10-Q/10-K, FAA directives, DOJ/court dockets, NASA posts) and date-stamp every fact
Verify and update legal/program statuses to Oct 2025 (e.g., DOJ case outcomes, 737 production caps, 777X timeline) and remove unverified speculation
Add an explicit ICP fit assessment and a concrete next step (pilot scope, timeline, success criteria, stakeholders)
Tighten to a <3-minute read: compress bullets, prioritize must-know data, move details to an appendix if needed
Follow the stated policy: note that web_search was used for verification and, if delivering iteratively, stream short deltas instead of a single monolith

results.name: Quick facts
results.output:
Quick facts: Lockheed Martin

- Legal name: Lockheed Martin Corporation (NYSE: LMT); formed March 15, 1995 via Lockheed–Martin Marietta merger. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_Martin?utm_source=openai))
- HQ: 6801 Rockledge Dr, Bethesda, Maryland 20817, USA. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm?utm_source=openai))
- Leadership (Oct 7, 2025): Jim Taiclet, Chairman, President & CEO; Evan Scott, CFO; Frank St. John, COO. ([lockheedmartin.com](https://www.lockheedmartin.com/en-us/who-we-are/leadership-governance/james-taiclet.html?utm_source=openai))
- FY2024 results (reported Jan 28, 2025): Net sales $71.0B; record backlog $176.0B; 2025 outlook provided. ([investors.lockheedmartin.com](https://investors.lockheedmartin.com/news-releases/news-release-details/lockheed-martin-reports-fourth-quarter-and-full-year-2024/?utm_source=openai))
- Employees: ~121,000 as of Dec 31, 2024 (≈70,000 in engineering/IT). ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
- Customer mix (2024): U.S. Government ~73% of sales; International ~26%; U.S. commercial ~1%. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
- Business areas: Aeronautics; Missiles & Fire Control (MFC); Rotary & Mission Systems (RMS); Space. ([lockheedmartin.com](https://lockheedmartin.com/en-us/who-we-are/business-areas.html?utm_source=openai))
- Largest program: F‑35 Lightning II (~26% of 2024 consolidated net sales; ~65% of Aeronautics). ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
- Key programs by area:
  - Aeronautics: F‑35, F‑16, C‑130, F‑22 sustainment. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
  - MFC: PAC‑3, THAAD, HIMARS/MLRS & GMLRS, JASSM/LRASM, Hellfire, PrSM, Javelin (JV with RTX). ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
  - RMS: Aegis Combat System, C2BMC, CH‑53K, Black Hawk/Seahawk, CRH, VH‑92A. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
  - Space: Trident II D5, Orion, GPS III, Next Gen OPIR, Transport Layer, NGI. ([sec.gov](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/936468/000093646825000009/lmt-20241231.htm))
- Recent highlights:
  - Selected by MDA to develop the Next Generation Interceptor (NGI). ([news.lockheedmartin.com](https://news.lockheedmartin.com/2024-04-15-U-S-Missile-Defense-Agency-selects-Lockheed-Martin-to-provide-its-Next-Generation-Interceptor?utm_source=openai))
  - Awarded up to $4.1B for C2BMC-Next. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/lockheed-wins-41-bln-battle-command-system-contract-us-govt-2024-04-11/?utm_source=openai))
  - Won $9.8B U.S. Army order for PAC‑3 MSE missiles (Sept 2025). ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/lockheed-martin-wins-98-billion-patriot-missile-contract-2025-09-03/?utm_source=openai))

Need a one-pager or account-specific angles?

issues: No proactive greeting or personalization to user/company/role
No hot signals surfaced with recommended sales actions
No summary stats block or smart suggestions
No upcoming meetings context or prep checklist
No executive summary upfront
No ICP fit assessment or decision criteria evaluation
No tailored next step for the AE at Nevereverordinary Labs
Decision-maker mapping limited to top execs; lacks functional buyers
Potential factual error: CFO likely not 'Evan Scott' (verify; historically Jay Malave)
Signals listed but not framed as sales-relevant insights
Did not explicitly follow 'stream short deltas' instruction
improvements: Open with a brief greeting addressing the user by name and role
Provide a 2–3 line executive summary at the top
Add a Summary Stats section (revenue, growth, backlog, headcount, segments, locations)
Surface ≥3 timely signals and attach a concrete sales action to each
Map ≥2 relevant functional decision makers (e.g., CIO/CTO, VP Digital Transformation, VP Supply Chain/Programs) with why-they-matter
Assess ICP fit and outline likely buying criteria; include a quick qualification checklist
Propose a clear, tailored next step for the AE (e.g., 15-min discovery with specific angle)
Include upcoming earnings/events and a prep checklist with talk tracks and questions
Verify leadership names and financials via latest 10-K/IR; correct the CFO
Keep it scannable under 3 minutes using clear headings and bullets
Cite sources inline with dates; use web_search to verify recency and accuracy

results.name: Specific question
results.query: Who is the CISO of Raytheon and recent security incidents?
results.output:
Here’s the latest:

Who’s the CISO
- Brad Maiorino, Corporate VP and Chief Information Security Officer at RTX (parent of Raytheon). ([aspendigital.org](https://www.aspendigital.org/person/brad-maiorino/?utm_source=openai))

Recent security incidents (past 12–18 months)
- Sep 19–24, 2025: Ransomware attack on Collins Aerospace’s MUSE airline check‑in/bag drop software (RTX unit); disclosed via 8‑K, caused airport disruptions across Europe. ([reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/airport-chaos-highlights-rise-high-profile-ransomware-attacks-cyber-experts-say-2025-09-22/))
- May 1, 2025: DOJ settlement—Raytheon Company/RTX/Nightwing to pay $8.4M over alleged non‑compliance with DoD cybersecurity requirements (DFARS/NIST 800‑171) on 2015–2021 contracts. ([justice.gov](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/raytheon-companies-and-nightwing-group-pay-84m-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations-relating?utm_source=openai))
- Aug 30, 2024: RTX fined $200M by U.S. State Department for export‑control violations; half suspended contingent on remedial compliance investments. ([wsj.com](https://www.wsj.com/articles/rtx-to-pay-200-million-over-export-control-violations-46d653b1?utm_source=openai))

Want me to confirm the current security lead for the Raytheon business unit specifically (separate from enterprise CISO)?

issues: No proactive greeting or personalization (name) to the user
Did not surface hot signals with recommended actions
No executive summary up front
Only one decision-maker named; missing ≥2 relevant security decision-makers (e.g., BU CISO/security leads)
No criteria-based evaluation of the signals (severity, impact, recency, relevance)
No ICP fit articulation or next-step recommendation tailored to the AE
No upcoming meetings surfaced or prep guidance
One item (export-control fine) is regulatory/compliance, not a cybersecurity incident
Potential accuracy risk: incidents may be unverified or mischaracterized; at least one appears questionable
Sources cited but not clearly validated via primary/official references (SEC filings, company press, CISA, DOJ)
No summary stats about the account/org to provide context
Did not clearly distinguish enterprise (RTX) CISO vs Raytheon business unit security lead (only offers to confirm later)
improvements: Open with a brief, personalized greeting and name the user; add a one-line executive summary of findings

Confirm the enterprise CISO via primary sources (RTX leadership page, recent press/SEC filings) and explicitly note the Raytheon BU security lead; list ≥2 decision-makers (e.g., Enterprise CISO, Deputy CISO, Raytheon BU CISO/Director of Cyber)
Provide ≥3 verified security signals strictly related to cybersecurity (breaches, ransomware, data exposure, federal cyber settlements), each with date, impact, scope, and relevance
Use primary sources for each signal (SEC 8-K/10-K/8-K, DOJ/CISA alerts, official company press releases) and include links
Add a concise criteria evaluation per signal (recency, severity, affected BU, operational impact, third-party vs internal, regulatory exposure)
Summarize account context: org structure (RTX vs Raytheon units), revenue/size, relevant cyber programs—keep it to quick stats
Surface hot signals into actions (e.g., outreach angle, proposed value props, timing) and tie to Nevereverordinary Labs’ ICP
Recommend clear next steps: who to contact, suggested messaging, meeting objective, and a 3-bullet prep checklist
Keep the read-time under 3 minutes with clear headings and tight bullet points
If uncertain items exist, explicitly label them as pending verification and queue a web search check with sources to confirm
